facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 178 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 178 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 6, 1962 of Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 1149 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 6, 1962, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 1149 of 1961.

facts.text: Appellant is one of four partners of a firm which owns a book-stall in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is one of four partners of a firm which owns a book-stall in Bombay. He was prosecuted along with the other partners under S. 292, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellant prosecuted along with other partners under S. 292 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: He was prosecuted along with the other partners under S. 292, Indian Penal Code. All the facts necessary for our purpose appear from the simple charge

facts.text: On 12 December 1959 at Bombay, accused Nos. 1,2,3,4 partners of Happy Book Stall found in possession for purpose of sale of obscene book Lady Chatterleys Lover unexpurgated edition.

anchor.surface_text: That you accused Nos. 1, 2, 3, 4 on or about the 12th day of December, 1959 at Bombay being the partners of a book-stall named Happy Book Stall were found in possession for the purpose of sale companyies of an obscene book called Lady Chatterleys Lover  unexpurgated edition  which inter alia companytained, obscene matter as detailed separately and attached herewith

facts.text: Appellant was accused No. 2 in the case.

anchor.surface_text: The first companynt applied to the appellant who was accused No. 2 in the case.

facts.text: Gokuldas Shamji on 12 December 1959 at Bombay sold to Bogus Customer Ali Raza Sayeed Hasan a copy of Lady Chatterleys Lover unexpurgated edition.

anchor.surface_text: and thereby companymitted an offence punishable u s 292 of the I.P. Code AND That you Gokuldas Shamji on or about the 12th day of December 1959 at Bombay did sell to Bogus Customer Ali Raza Sayeed Hasan a companyy of an obscene book called Lady Chatterleys Lover  unexpurgated edition

facts.text: Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, III Court, Esplanade, Bombay convicted all partners on first count and fined each Rs. 20 with one week simple imprisonment in default.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, III Court, Esplanade, Bombay, companyvicted all the partners on the first companynt and fined each of them Rs. 20 with one weeks simple imprisonment in default.

facts.text: Gokuldas Shamji additionally convicted on second count and sentenced to further fine of Rs. 20 or like imprisonment in default.

anchor.surface_text: Gokuldas Shamji was additionally companyvicted on the second companynt and was sentenced to a further fine of Rs. 20 or like imprisonment in default.

facts.text: Magistrate held that the offending book was obscene for purposes of S.292.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate held that the offending book was obscene for purposes of the section.

facts.text: Present appellant filed revision in High Court of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The present appellant filed a revision in the High Court of Bombay. The decision of the High Court was against him.

facts.text: Bombay High Court decision against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the High Court was against him. He has number appealed to this Court by special leave

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: He has number appealed to this Court by special leave and has raised the issue of freedom of speech and expression guaranteed by the nineteenth Article.

facts.text: Prosecution examined two witnesses: test purchaser named in charge (Ali Raza Sayeed Hasan) and Inspector of Vigilance Department.

anchor.surface_text: To prove the requirements of the section the prosecution examined two witnesses. One was the test purchaser named in the charge and the other an Inspector of the Vigilance Department.

facts.text: Witnesses proved possession and sale of the book, facts not denied.

anchor.surface_text: These witnesses proved possession and sale of the book which facts are number denied.

facts.text: Inspector offered reasons for considering the book obscene.

anchor.surface_text: The Inspector in his testimony also offered his reasons for companysidering the book to be obscene.

facts.text: Mr. Mulkraj Anand, writer and art critic, gave evidence for accused that novel has considerable literary merit, classic, not obscene.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the accused Mr. Mulkraj Anand, a writer and art critic gave evidence and in a detailed analysis of the numberel, he sought to establish that in spite of its apparent indelicate theme and the candidness of its delineation and diction, the numberel was a work of companysiderable literary merit and a classic and number obscene.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds book obscene under S.292 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: When everything said in its favour we find that in treating with sex the impugned portions viewed separately and also in the setting of the whole book pass the permissible limits judged of from our companymunity standards and as there is numbersocial gain to us which can be said to preponderate, we must hold the book to satisfy the test we have indicated above.

facts.text: High Court right in dismissing revision petition.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyclusion we are of the opinion that the High Court was right in dismissing the revision petition.

facts.text: S.292 IPC introduced by Obscene Publications Act 7 of 1925 to give effect to Article 1 of International Convention signed by India in 1923 at Geneva.

anchor.surface_text: The section of the Penal Code in dispute was introduced by the Obscene Publications Act  7 of 1925  to give effect to Article 1 of the International Convention for the suppression of or traffic in obscene publications signed by India in 1923 at Geneva.

issues.text: s. 292 of the Indian Penal Code is void as being an impermissible and vague restriction on the freedom of speech and expression guaranteed by Art. 19(1)(a) and is not saved by cl. (2) of the same article

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg who argued the case with ability, raised these two issues. He bases his argument on three legal grounds which briefly are that s. 292 of the Indian Penal Code is void as being an impermissible and vague restriction on the freedom of speech and expression guaranteed by Art. 19(1)(a) and is not saved by cl. (2) of the same article

holdings.text: Section 292, Indian Penal Code deals with obscenity in this sense and cannot thus be said to be invalid in view of the second clause of Art. 19.

anchor.surface_text: Section 292, Indian Penal Code deals with obscenity in this sense and cannot thus be said to be invalid in view of the second clause of Art. 19.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.292 imposes reasonable restrictions on speech for public decency and morality under Art.19(2); obscenity excluded from protection; term not vague; aligns with international convention.

holdings.text: We do not accept this argument. The first sub-section of s. 292 unlike some others which open with the words whoever knowingly or negligently etc. does not make knowledge of obscenity an ingredient of the offence.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with that problem we wish to dispose of Mr. Gargs third argument that the prosecution must prove that the person who sells or keeps for sale any obscene object knows that it is obscene, before he can be adjudged guilty. We do not accept this argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading shows no 'knowingly' requirement unlike other sections; strict liability avoids proof difficulties; mens rea inferred from circumstances.

holdings.text: Here, of course, the ordinary guilty intention (mens rea) will be required before the offence can be said to be complete. The offender must have actually sold or kept for sale, the offending article. The circumstances of the case will then determine the criminal intent and it will be a matter of a proper inference from them.

anchor.surface_text: Next to consider is the second part of the guilty act (actus reus), namely, the selling or keeping for sale of an object which is found to be obscene. Here, of course, the ordinary guilty intention (mens rea) will be required before the offence can be said to be complete.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mens rea for actus reus of sale/possession inferred circumstantially; no positive proof needed beyond circumstances; strict responsibility traditional in obscenity law.

holdings.text: This test has been uniformly applied in India. The important question is whether this test of obscenity squares with the freedom of speech and expression guaranteed under our Constitution, or it needs to be modified and, if so, in what respects.

anchor.surface_text: This test has been uniformly applied in India. The important question is whether this test of obscenity squares with the freedom of speech and expression guaranteed under our Constitution, or it needs to be modified and, if so, in what respects.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hicklin test retained but modified to view book as whole, assess overall effect and redeeming merit; balances constitutional freedom with decency.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the test to adopt in our country regard being had to our community mores is that obscenity without a preponderating social purpose or profit cannot have the constitutional protection of free speech and expression, and obscenity is treating with sex in a manner appealing to the carnal side of human nature, or having that tendency.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the test to adopt in our country regard being had to our community mores is that obscenity without a preponderating social purpose or profit cannot have the constitutional protection of free speech and expression, and obscenity is treating with sex in a manner appealing to the carnal side of human nature, or having that tendency.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evolves test considering community standards, whole work, preponderant social value over prurient appeal; art must overshadow obscenity.

holdings.text: When everything said in its favour we find that in treating with sex the impugned portions viewed separately and also in the setting of the whole book pass the permissible limits judged of from our community standards and as there is no social gain to us which can be said to preponderate, we must hold the book to satisfy the test we have indicated above.

anchor.surface_text: When everything said in its favour we find that in treating with sex the impugned portions viewed separately and also in the setting of the whole book pass the permissible limits judged of from our community standards and as there is no social gain to us which can be said to preponderate, we must hold the book to satisfy the test we have indicated above.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies modified test to facts: portions deprave without preponderating merit per community mores; literary claims insufficient.

holdings.text: In the conclusion we are of the opinion that the High Court was right in dismissing the revision petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms lower courts on obscenity finding and conviction under S.292.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with that problem we wish to dispose of Mr. Gargs third argument that the prosecution must prove that the person who sells or keeps for sale any obscene object knows that it is obscene, before he can be adjudged guilty. We do not accept this argument.

anchor.surface_text: Next to consider is the second part of the guilty act (actus reus), namely, the selling or keeping for sale of an object which is found to be obscene. Here, of course, the ordinary guilty intention (mens rea) will be required before the offence can be said to be complete.

anchor.surface_text: This test has been uniformly applied in India. The important question is whether this test of obscenity squares with the freedom of speech and expression guaranteed under our Constitution, or it needs to be modified and, if so, in what respects.
In the companyclusion we are of the opinion that the High Court was right in dismissing the revision petition.

In our opinion, the test to adopt in our country regard being had to our community mores is that obscenity without a preponderating social purpose or profit cannot have the constitutional protection of free speech and expression, and obscenity is treating with sex in a manner appealing to the carnal side of human nature, or having that tendency.
In the companyclusion we are of the opinion that the High Court was right in dismissing the revision petition.

anchor.surface_text: When everything said in its favour we find that in treating with sex the impugned portions viewed separately and also in the setting of the whole book pass the permissible limits judged of from our community standards and as there is no social gain to us which can be said to preponderate, we must hold the book to satisfy the test we have indicated above.
